@InProceedings{Bakhvalov:1994:FDM,
  author =       "N. S. Bakhvalov and A. Knyazev",
  editor =       "G. I. Marchuk",
  booktitle =    "Numerical Methods and Applications",
  title =        "Fictitious domain methods and computation of
                 homogenized properties of composites with a periodic
                 structure of essentially different components",
  publisher =    pub-CRC,
  address =      "Boca Raton",
  pages =        "221--276",
  year =         "1994",
  abstract =     "There are many important physical problems that can be
                 modeled using partial differential equations (PDE) with
                 discontinuous coefficients. Drops of the coefficients
                 may be very large. We consider one class of those
                 problems concerning composites of essentially different
                 components. Composites or composite materials are said
                 to be media with a large number of non homogeneous
                 inclusions with small sizes at least along one
                 direction. Stationary states of that media is described
                 by elliptic PDE with highly oscillated coefficients.
                 The homogenization is said to be a process of finding
                 such homogeneous coefficients that a solution of
                 original PDE can be approximated by the solution of the
                 same PDE, but with these new homogeneous coefficients
                 instead of old highly oscillated coefficients.
                 Computation of homogenized coefficients of composites
                 with periodic structure reduces to solving a series of
                 periodic boundary value problem for the original PDE in
                 the domain, called cell, of periodicity. For composites
                 of essentially different components the coefficients of
                 the PDE in the domain of periodicity are discontinuous
                 and have big jumps. Another important source of PDE
                 with jumps of coefficients is Fictitious Domain Method.
                 In this method the original boundary value problem for
                 PDE is changed for a new boundary value problem in a
                 domain that covers the original one. In the new
                 fictitious part of the domain the coefficients of PDE
                 are chosen about zero for {Neumann} original boundary
                 conditions or very large for {Dirichlet} original
                 boundary conditions, such that a solution of the new
                 problem approximates or, even, coincides with the
                 desired solution. Therefore, the fictitious domain
                 methods makes possible to ``improve'' the shape of the
                 original boundary, but leads to a PDE with very large
                 jumps of coefficients. We consider here a nonstandard
                 variant of the fictitious domain method, namely, with
                 periodic boundary conditions on the fictitious
                 boundary. For this variant the problem produced by the
                 fictitious domain method looks exactly like a problem
                 produced by the homogenization procedure we were
                 talking about, i.e., that is a periodic boundary value
                 problem in a cube for elliptic PDE with discontinuous
                 coefficients that can achieve, in limit cases, zero or
                 infinitely large values. There are several different
                 difficulties associated with numerical solution of
                 those problems. In the present paper we consider only
                 one of them, concerned with the rate of convergence of
                 preconditioned iterative methods. It is well known,
                 that, typically, the larger is the jumps of
                 coefficient, the slower is the convergence. Our main
                 goal is to prove, that with a special initial guess the
                 rate of convergence does not depend on the value of the
                 jumps. We do not touch here the mesh approximations of
                 our PDE, but we can expect that for some natural types
                 of approximations all our results still hold and the
                 rate of convergence does not depend of the mesh size
                 parameter as well. The central idea of the proof is
                 that with the special initial guess errors of all
                 iterative steps belong to a subspace and in this
                 subspace our problem is well posed independently of the
                 jumps of coefficients. We also consider some related
                 questions, e.g., the dependence of the solution of
                 small coefficients in a subdomain",
}

@InProceedings{Boccardo:1989:ESW,
  author =       "L. Boccardo and J. I. D{\'\i}az and D. Giachetti and

  booktitle =    "Recent advances in nonlinear elliptic and parabolic
                 problems (Nancy, 1988)",

  abstract =     "Consider the nonlinear elliptic equation
                 \setcounter{equation}{0} \begin{equation} - div (A \
                 grad \ u) - div (\phi(u)) = f \ \mbox{in} \ \Omega, u
                 \in H{_{0}^{1}}(\Omega) \end{equation}, where $A$ is a
                 ${(L^\infty(\Omega))}^{N \times N}$ coercive matrix, $f
                 \in H{^{-1}}(\Omega)$ and $\phi \in {(C^0(R))}^N$; no
                 growth restriction is assumed on $\phi$; thus the term
                 $div (\phi(u))$ cannot be understood in the
                 distributional sense. In this paper we prove the
                 existence of a solution of \setcounter{equation}{1}
                 \begin{equation} [- div (A \ grad \ u)] h(u) - div
                 (\phi(u) h(u) ) + \phi(u)h'(u) \ grad \ u = f h(u) \
                 \mbox{in} \ \Omega, \forall h \in C{_{c}^{1}}(\Omega)
                 \end{equation} where in contrast with (1) every term
                 has a meaning in $D'(\Omega)$ if $u \in
                 H{{_0}{^1}}(\Omega)$. Equation (2) is a weaker form of
                 the original problem, obtained in a formal way through
                 a pointwise multiplication of (1) by $h(u)$.",

@TechReport{Bourgeat:1994:RRD,

                 Immiscible Two-Phase Flow",
  number =       "186",
  institution =  "Equipe d'Analyse Num{\'e}rique Lyon Saint-Etienne,
                 CNRS URA 740",
  year =         "1994",
  abstract =     "In this paper we justify by periodic homogenization
                 the double porosity model for immiscible incompressible
                 two-phase flows. The volume fraction of the fissured
                 part and the nonfissured part are kept positive
                 constants and of same order. The scaling is such that,
                 in the final homogenized equations, the less permeable
                 part of the matrix contributes as a nonlinear memory
                 term. For the first part of the proof we use the
                 two-scale convergence as it seems to be appropriate for
                 the problem, even though to work with periodic
                 modulation would be possible. The fact that the
                 equations are nonlinear and degenerated parabolic means
                 that in the final step of the convergence proof of the
                 other hand we have to use periodic modulation instead
                 of two-scale convergence.",
}

@Article{Bourgeat:1995:EET,
  author =       "A. Bourgeat and S. M. Kozlov and A. Mikeli{\'c}",
  title =        "Effective equations of two-phase flow in random
                 media",
  journal =      j-CALC-VAR-PARTIAL-DIFFER-EQU,
  volume =       "3",
  number =       "3",
  pages =        "385--406",
  year =         "1995",
  ISSN =         "0944-2669",
  abstract =     "We consider the behavior of incompressible two-phase
                 flow in heterogeneous reservoirs with randomly placed
                 heterogeneities; that is, in media with permeability
                 $A$ and porosity $\Phi$ which are stochastically
                 homogeneous stationary random fields. We assume both
                 the Darcy velocity and the diffusion flux being given
                 nonlinear functions of the concentration. Using the
                 tools of stochastic homogenization we get the nonlinear
                 effective equations which govern the flow behavior in a
                 homogeneous medium, being equivalent in the sense of
                 homogenization theory, to the original one. When
                 $\epsilon$ is small the randomly heterogeneous porous
                 medium behaves like a deterministic medium with
                 effective permeability tensor $A^0$. It is shown how to
                 calculate the effective permeability tensor $A^0$ by
                 solving auxiliary stochastic problems. Using the
                 rescaling parameter $\epsilon$, corresponding to the
                 characteristic scale of heterogeneities, we prove the
                 convergence of the homogenization process for $\epsilon
                 \longrightarrow 0$. Furthermore, by using regularity
                 results for the nonlinear effective equations we
                 construct the correctors and establish strong
                 convergence.",
  fjournal =     "Calculus of Variations and Partial Differential
                 Equations",
}

@Article{Bourgeat:19xx:HPF,
  author =       "A. Bourgeat and A. Mikelic",
  title =        "Homogenization of a polymer flow through a porous
                 medium",
  journal =      j-NONLINEAR-ANAL,
  year =         "19xx",
  CODEN =        "NOANDD",
  ISSN =         "0362-546X",
  abstract =     "We derive the constitutive laws that connect the
                 velocity and the pressure gradient in stationary
                 incompressible purely viscous non-Newtonian flow
                 through porous media. Starting from the stationary
                 non-Newtonian Navier-{Stokes} system, with viscosity
                 obeying Carreau and power laws, and using the
                 homogenization theory, we obtain a variety of laws
                 according to the size of Reynolds number. It appears
                 that there is a critical Reynolds number such that
                 after reaching it the flow regime in porous media
                 changes from a linear, Darcy's type law, to a nonlinear
                 and nonlocal law. We prove uniqueness for the
                 homogenized problem. The proof of convergence is given
                 under the usual assumption of periodic geometry",
  ams =          "35B27, 35Q30, 76a05, 76d05, 76s05",

                 abstract framework in order to pass to the limit in
                 (1): the idea is to suppose the existence of good test
                 functions $w^\varepsilon$, as in the energy method in
                 the theory of homogenization; we obtain an equation of
                 type (2), with $\mu \in H^{-1}(\Omega), \mu \ge 0$. The
                 method can be extended to {Dirichlet} problems of any
                 order. In the second part, we give examples. In the
                 third part, we prove (in the abstract framework) the
                 lower semi-continuity of the energy and the following
                 result: the solution $u^\varepsilon$ of (1) (apart from
                 a remainder which goes strongly to zero) is the product
                 of the test function $w^\varepsilon$ by the limit
                 function $u$, which is the solution of (2). The fourth
                 part is devoted to the study of variational

@TechReport{Donato:1993:RCR,
  author =       "P. Donato",
  title =        "Recent controllability results for the wave equation
                 in domains with small holes",
  institution =  "Publications du Laboratoire d'Analyse Num{\'e}rique,
                 Universit{\'e} Pierre et Marie Curie",
  year =         "1993",
  abstract =     "An important problem in the application is the
                 controllability for perturbed systems. A special kind
                 of perturbed systems, depending on a small parameter
                 $\epsilon$, is the wave equation when the coefficients
                 are rapidly oscillating or when posed in periodically
                 perforated domains. A limit system (in the
                 homogenization theory sense) can be defined in some
                 cases. Then, two main questions can be formulated: (i)
                 does the exact controllability problem converges as $
                 \epsilon \longrightarrow 0$ to the control problem for
                 the limit system? (ii) is it possible to control
                 approximately the perturbated system in order to
                 obtain, as $\epsilon \longrightarrow 0$, exact
                 controllability at the limit? We present here a review
                 of some results for the exact and approximate
                 controllability answering to these questions.",

@TechReport{Dvorak:1994:RNM,
  author =       "J. Dvo{\v{r}}{\'a}k",
  title =        "A Reliable Numerical Method for Computing Homogenized
                 Coefficients",
  number =       "MAT-Report 31",
  institution =  "Mathematical Institute, Danish Technical University",
  address =      "Lyngby, Denmark",
  year =         "1994",
  abstract =     "The problem of calculation of the effective
                 conductivity matrix of a periodic composite is treated
                 using convex analysis techniques. We show that results
                 of a conforming numerical solution of the primal
                 formulation of the homogenization formula converge to
                 the exact values from above, while numerical solutions
                 of the dual formulation converge from below. The
                 difference of the two numerical results provides a
                 reliable estimate of the numerical error in the
                 effective conductivities. We suggest a p-hierarchical
                 version of the FEM for the solution of the periodic PDE
                 problem that is involved; the numerical error estimate
                 provides a sound basis for adaptivity. We present
                 several numerical examples",
}

@Article{Francfort:1994:CEH,
  author =       "G. A. Francfort and S. M{\"u}ller",
  title =        "Combined Effects of Homogenization and Singular
                 Perturbations in Elasticity",
  journal =      j-J-REINE-ANGEW-MATH,
  volume =       "454",
  pages =        "1--35",
  year =         "1994",
  CODEN =        "JRMAA8",
  ISSN =         "0075-4102",
  MRclass =      "73B27 (35B27 49J45 73C50 73V25)",
  MRnumber =     "95h:73007",
  abstract =     "The combined effects of small heterogeneities and
                 higher order perturbations for both linear and fully
                 nonlinear elastic materials are discussed. In the
                 linear case the theory of $H$-convergence is extended
                 to allow for the inclusion of higher order
                 perturbations. As an application the case of periodic
                 heterogeneities is studied in detail. Specifically it
                 is shown that the limiting problem corresponding to $ -
                 \mbox{div} A (x/\epsilon^\gamma) \mbox{grad} u^\epsilon
                 + \epsilon^2 \nabla^2 u^\epsilon = f$ is given by $ -
                 \mbox{div} A^0 \mbox{grad} \ u = f$, where $A^0$ equals
                 the classical $H$-limit if $\gamma \le 1$ (i.e. if the
                 length scale of the heterogeneities is large compared
                 to the scale $\epsilon$ introduced by the
                 perturbation), while $A^0$ is the average of $A$ is
                 $\gamma \ge 1$. In the intermediate case $\gamma = 1$
                 both the heterogeneities and the higher order
                 perturbation contribute to $A^0$. Analogous results are
                 established in the nonlinear setting by studying the
                 $\Gamma$-limit of the functionals $\int W
                 (x/\epsilon^\gamma, \mbox{grad} \ u) + \epsilon^2
                 {(\nabla \ u)}^2$",
  ams =          "Subject 35B25, 73C40 (49B21, 73C60)",
}

@TechReport{Jager:1993:HLE,

  year =         "1993",
  abstract =     "We consider the {Laplace} equation in a bounded domain
                 consisting of a porous medium, a nonperforated domain
                 and an interface between them. The homogeneous
                 Dirichlet's condition is prescribed on the boundaries
                 of the perforations. We suppose the porous medium
                 having a periodic structure with a period $\epsilon$
                 and consider the limit $\epsilon \longrightarrow 0$.
                 The effective behaviors inside the porous medium and
                 the nonperforated domain are obtained and in addition
                 the boundary conditions to be imposed at the interface
                 between two media are determined. Using the boundary
                 layers describing interaction between two very
                 different media we estimate the $L^2$-norm of the
                 difference between the solution $u^\epsilon$ of the
                 $\epsilon$-problem and the effective behavior terms and
                 show that it is bounded from above by
                 $C\epsilon^{\frac{1}{2}}$. Finally, we calculate the
                 weak $L^2$-limit of the renormalized function
                 $\frac{u^\epsilon}{\epsilon^2}$ and weak
                 $M(\Omega)$-limit of the renormalized $\nabla
                 \frac{u^\epsilon} {\epsilon^2}$.",
}

@TechReport{Jager:1994:BCC,
  author =       "W. J{\"a}ger and Andro Mikeli{\'c}",

  abstract =     "We consider a slow viscous flow in a two-dimensional
                 domain consisting of a porous medium and a free fluid
                 domain. At the boundaries of the solid part of porous
                 medium we suppose the no-slip boundary condition.
                 Supposing a periodic porous medium with period
                 proportional to the characteristic pore size and a
                 fixed porosity and using the homogenization, we find
                 conditions on the interface linking pressures and
                 velocities. Furthermore, we estimate the $L^2$-norm of
                 the difference between the solution for some pores size
                 $\varepsilon $ and the combination of solutions of the
                 limit problems and show the convergence as
                 $\varepsilon$ tends to zero. We distinguish (a) the
                 balanced flow in free fluid domain and in porous medium
                 and (b) the small flow in porous medium caused by the
                 flow in free fluid domain. In the case (a) we obtain
                 continuity of the normal velocities at the interface
                 and the value of Darcy's pressure at the interface is
                 equal to zero. In (b) at the interface difference
                 between the Darcy pressure and the pressure of free
                 fluid is proportional to the tangential component of
                 the viscous stress corresponding to the free fluid. The
                 free fluid flow is behaving as an uncoupled {Stokes}
                 flow with no slip condition for the velocity at the
                 interface.",

@Article{Jurak:19xx:HCO,
  author =       "M. Jurak",
  title =        "Homogenization of Capillary Oscillations of an
                 Inviscid Fluid in a Porous Reservoir",
  journal =      j-BOLL-UNIONE-MAT-ITAL,
  year =         "19xx",
  CODEN =        "BLUMAM",
  ISSN =         "0041-7084",
  abstract =     "We consider small gravitational oscillations of an
                 ideal fluid in a cylindrical reservoir. Besides
                 gravity, surface tension at the free boundary is
                 considered. The reservoir contains a large number of
                 vertical solid tubes, periodically distributed over the
                 reservoir's cross section. Taking the period $\epsilon$
                 of the structure as parameter we get a sequence of
                 generalized eigenproblems. We find the limit problem
                 when the period $\epsilon$ tends to zero. Furthermore,
                 we show convergence of the eigenvalues and the
                 eigenspaces of the hydrodynamical problems towards that
                 of the limit problem. In the proof we use a
                 modification of theorem due to Yosifian, Oleinik and
                 Shamaev [Uspechi. Mat. Nauk. 44 (1989), 157-158]",
}

                 isotropy.",

@TechReport{Lipton:1993:HTP,
  author =       "R. Lipton and B. Vernescu",
  title =        "Homogenization of Two Phase Emulsions with Surface
                 Tension Effects",
  number =       "1139",
  institution =  "Institute for Mathematics and Its Applications,
                 Minnesota",
  year =         "1993",
  abstract =     "We consider an emulsion of two {Stokes} fluids, one of
                 which is periodically distributed in the form of small
                 spherical bubbles. The effects of surface tension on
                 the bubble boundaries are modelled mathematically, as
                 in the work of G. I. Taylor, by a jump only in the
                 normal component of the traction. For a given volume
                 fraction of bubbles we consider the two-scale
                 convergence, and in the fine phase limit we find that
                 the bulk flow is described by an anisotropic {Stokes}
                 fluid. The effective viscosity tensor is consistent
                 with the bulk stress formula obtained by {Batchelor}.
                 We find a new dual variational principle describing the
                 effective viscosity and obtain bound on the energy
                 dissipation rate for periodic anisotropic emulsions.",
  keywords =     "homogenization, emulsions, surface tension, effective
                 viscosity, bounds",
}

@TechReport{Lipton:19xx:BPT,
  author =       "R. Lipton and B. Vernescu",
  title =        "Bulk properties of two phase emulsions with surface
                 tension effects",
  year =         "19xx",
  abstract =     "We consider an emulsion of two {Stokes} fluids, one of
                 which is in the form of small bubbles held spherical by
                 surface tension. The effect of surface tension is
                 modeled by Taylor's conditions on the normal stress and
                 velocity at the two fluid interface. For a given volume
                 fraction of bubbles we consider the fine phase limit of
                 a family of periodic emulsions. We find in the
                 asymptotic limit that the bulk flow has a viscosity
                 tensor consistent with the bulk stress formula obtained
                 by {Batchelor} (1970). We find a new dual variational
                 principle describing the effective viscosity and obtain
                 bounds on the energy dissipation rate for periodic
                 anisotropic emulsions. These bounds are precisely the
                 arithmetic and harmonic mean of the two viscosities.",

                 viscosity, bounds",

  year =         "1993",
  abstract =     "Let $A$ be a linear elliptic operator of the second
                 order with bounded measurable coefficients on a bounded
                 open set $ \Omega$ of $R^n$, and let $(\Omega_h)$ be an
                 arbitrary sequence of open subsets of $\Omega$. We
                 prove the following compactness result: there exist a
                 subsequence, still denoted by $(\Omega_h)$, and a
                 positive Borel measure $\mu$ on $\Omega$, not charging
                 polar sets, such that, for every $f \in H^{-1}
                 (\Omega)$, the solutions $u_h \in H{^{1}_{0}}
                 (\Omega_h)$ of the equations $Au_h = f$ in $\Omega_h$,
                 extended to $0$ on $\Omega \setminus \Omega_h$,
                 converge weakly in $H{^{1}_{0}} (\Omega)$ to the unique
                 solution $u \in H{^{1}_{0}} (\Omega) \cap L{^{2}_{\mu}
                 (\Omega)}$ of the problem $$ \langle Au, v \rangle +
                 \int_\Omega uvd \mu = \langle f, v \rangle \ \ \
                 \forall v \in H{^{1}_{0}} (\Omega) \cap L{^{2}_{\mu}}
                 (\Omega).$$ When $A$ is symmetric, this compactness
                 result is already known and was obtained by
                 $\Gamma$-convergence techniques. Our new proof, based
                 on the method of oscillating test functions, extends
                 the result to the non-symmetric case. The new
                 technique, which is completely independent of
                 $\Gamma$-convergence, relies on the study of the
                 behaviour $w{^{*}_{h}} \in H{^{1}_{0}} (\Omega_h)$ of
                 the equations $A^* w{^{*}_{h}} = 1$ in $\Omega_h$,
                 where $A^*$ is the adjoint operator. We prove also that
                 the limit measure $\mu$ does not change if $A$ is
                 replaced by $A^*$. Moreover, we prove that $\mu$
                 depends only on the symmetric part of the operator $A$,
                 if the coefficients of the skew-symmetric part are
                 continuous, while an explicit example shows that $\mu$
                 may depend also on the skew-symmetric part of $A$, when
                 the coefficients are discontinuous.",

@Article{Mikelic:1994:HHE,
  author =       "A. Mikeli{\'c} and M. Primicerio",

  title =        "Homogenization of the Heat Equation for a Domain with

  CODEN =        "ANLMAE",
  ISSN =         "0373-3114",
  abstract =     "We consider the linear heat equation in a domain
                 occupied by a solid material with a network of pipes in
                 which a well-mixed fluid is circulating. The
                 temperature of the fluid in the pipe is uniform and its
                 time variation is determined by the thermal flux on the
                 wall of the pipe, plus a given internal source;
                 continuity of the temperature across the pipe is also
                 assumed. We suppose that we deal with a periodic
                 geometry, with cells of size $\epsilon$ with inclusions
                 of size $r_\epsilon$; we study in detail in the case
                 $r_\epsilon \sim \epsilon$, referring to a previous
                 paper for the case $r_\epsilon << \epsilon$. In the
                 limit $\epsilon \longrightarrow 0$ we get a homogenized
                 equation. The limit depends strongly on the ratio
                 between the time variation of the temperature in the
                 inclusions and the thermal flux through the interface.
                 The homogenized equation has a new specific heat, which
                 depends on the porosity and the constant of
                 proportionality between the time variation of
                 temperature and the flux on the boundary of the pipe.
                 We also have a new thermal conductivity depending on
                 the microstructure, and volume sources appear. The main
                 tool is the energy method and we generalize the
                 classical results for the more standard boundary
                 conditions for parabolic equations. Finally, we
                 consider the network of pipes forming a random ball
                 structure. We prove convergence for this case. The
                 homogenized equation is of the same form as in the
                 periodic case but auxiliary problems are stochastic.",
}

@TechReport{Murat:1993:SRE,
  author =       "F. Murat",
  title =        "Soluciones renormalizadas de {EDP} elipticas no
                 lineales (in {Spanish})",
  number =       "R 93023",
  institution =  "Publications du Laboratoire d'Analyse Num{\'e}rique,
                 Universit{\'e} Pierre et Marie Curie",
  year =         "1993",
  abstract =     "This paper consists of the notes of a series of
                 lectures I gave at the University of Seville in May
                 1992. The problem under consideration is $- div (A \
                 grad \ u) - div(\phi(u)) + \lambda u = f \ \mbox{in}
                 \Omega, u = 0 \ \mbox{on} \ \partial \Omega$, where $A$
                 is a coercive matrix with coefficients in $L^\infty
                 (\Omega), \phi : R \longrightarrow R^N$ is a locally
                 Lipschitz continuous function (no growth condition on
                 $\phi$ is assumed), $\lambda$ is strictly positive and
                 $f$ belongs to $L^1(\Omega)$. The definition of
                 renormalized solution of this problem is introduced.
                 The renormalized solution is proved to exist and to be
                 unique.",
}

@TechReport{Skrypnik:1994:HND,
  author =       "Igor V. Skrypnik",
  title =        "Homogenization of Nonlinear {Dirichlet} Problems in
                 Perforated Domains of General Structure",
  number =       "196/94/M",
  institution =  "S.I.S.S.A. ISAS",
  address =      "Trieste, Italy",
  month =        dec,
  year =         "1994",
  abstract =     "We consider a sequence of boundary value problems for
                 nonlinear elliptic equations in divergence form in
                 domains $\Omega_s \subset \Omega \subset {\bf R^n}, s =
                 1,2, \ldots$. Our hypothesis about the structure of the
                 sets $\Omega_s$ is the following: there exists a
                 sequence $r_s$ tending to zero such that the inequality
                 $C_m(K(x_0,r) \setminus \Omega_s) f \le Ar^n$ is valid
                 for every $x_0 \in \Omega$ and every $r \ge r_s$, where
                 $C_m$ is the $m-$capacity, $m$ is related to the growth
                 conditions of the operators associated with the
                 differential equations, and $K(x_0, r)$ denotes the
                 cube with centre $x_0$ and edge $2r$. We study tyhe
                 strong convergence in $L_p, p < m$ of the derivatives
                 of $u_s(x)$ and construct a boundary value problem
                 satisfied by the limit function. We construct also a
                 corrector for the approximation of $u_s(x)$ in
                 $W_{m}^{1}$. All our results are based on the
                 asymptotic expansion of the sequence $u_s(x)$ and on a
                 pointwise estimate of the solutions of a model
                 nonlinear boundary value problem.",
}

  journal =      j-QUART-J-MECH-APPLIED-MATH,
  volume =       "49",
  number =       "4",
  pages =        "565--580",
  year =         "1996",
  CODEN =        "QJMMAV",
  ISSN =         "0033-5614",
  abstract =     "In this paper, we extend the equi-strength concept to
                 optimize the elastic behaviour of two-dimensional
                 grained composites in which identical foreign
                 inclusions form rhombic network interacting with the
                 principal material. The analytical solution based upon
                 the complex-valued potentials of Kolosov-Muskhelishvili
                 employs the doubly periodic Weierstrass elliptic
                 functions of a negative determinantto obtain,
                 explicitly, the parametric equations of the equi-stress
                 contours. To the author's best knowledge,
                 non-rectangular period cells have never been considered
                 in the literature, so this paper may be regarded as a
                 first attempt to advance in this direction. It is shown
                 that the lattice type has little influence on the
                 stress field in the composites, but is predominant for
                 the shaping of the optimal inclusions.",

  author =       "V. V. Yurinsky",
  title =        "Covariance Bounds for Means with respect to
                 Distributions of Switching Diffusions in Random
                 Environment",
  journal =      j-SIBERIAN-ADV-MATH,
  volume =       "1",
  number =       "2",
  pages =        "185--199",

  ISSN =         "1055-1344",

  abstract =     "The paper considers resolvents of matrix elliptic
                 operators in the case when these admit an explicit
                 probabilistic representation by a continuum integral
                 with respect to the distribution of a nondegenerate
                 diffusion in random environment. The coefficients of
                 the operator are assumed to satisfy a uniform strong
                 mixing condition. Under this restriction nontrivial
                 bounds are shown to exist for covariances of the
                 spatial averages over large blocks for random fields
                 solving certain second-order elliptic systems with
                 random coefficients. Bounds of this type are used in
                 evaluation of the error caused by approximation of the
                 solution of a well-posed boundary problem with random
                 highly oscillating coefficients by that of its
                 homogenized counterpart.",
  keywords =     "homogenization, averaging, random environment, random
                 media, diffusion, homogenization error",

@Article{Yurinsky:1991:HEZ,
  author =       "V. V. Yurinsky",
  title =        "On the Homogenization Error for a Zero Drift Diffusion
                 in a Random Medium",
  journal =      j-SIBERIAN-ADV-MATH,
  volume =       "1",
  number =       "4",
  pages =        "186--197",
  year =         "1991",
  ISSN =         "1055-1344",
  note =         "Translated from PRIM 20.",
  abstract =     "This paper studies the resolvent operator of the
                 generator of a nondegenerate diffusion with zero drift
                 in a random environment. The coefficients of the
                 generator are assumed to form a random field that is
                 homogeneous with respect to integer-valued translations
                 and satisfies a uniform strong mixing condition. The
                 main result is a bound on the covariances of a random
                 field obtained by applying the resolvent to a bounded
                 field of the above type. This bound can be used to
                 deduce error estimates which vanish as positive powers
                 of the small parameter for the homogenization
                 approximations to solutions of standard boundary
                 problems for elliptic operators of above type with
                 highly oscillating random coefficients. Inequalities of
                 this paper are derived without Cordes-type restrictions
                 on the span of eigenvalues of the diffusion matrix:
                 they are nontrivial in dimensions $d \ge 4$, while
                 earlier results of this kind applied to the case $d \ge
                 5$. The improvement is due to a new version of an
                 argument used to localize the dependence of the
                 resolvent operator on the diffusion matrix through a
                 decomposition of averages with respect to the
                 distribution of diffusion in its path space into means
                 over ''tubes'' of trajectories.",
  keywords =     "homogenization, error estimates, diffusion in random
                 environment, random media",
}
